results.headline: Orphans Searching for Hope
results.summary_short: “My Brother” is billed as the tale of two poor, orphaned siblings, but it wants to be much more than that.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Brother

results.headline: Religion With Guns
results.summary_short: “Adam’s Apples” — about a neo-Nazi sentenced to community service at a rural church — is a weird mix of glib humor with dead-serious spiritual inquiry.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Adam's Apples

results.headline: A Prodigy’s Life Is Played Out in a Japanese Game of Skill
results.summary_short: Tian Zhuangzhuang’s biopic is a stately and respectful reflection on the life of Wu Qingyuan, one of the 20th century’s top players of go, a Japanese game said to rival chess in complexity.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Go Master

results.headline: Setting Sail on a Bumpy Cruise With the Shadowy Shostakovich
results.summary_short: A documentary grab bag of film clips, diary readings and desultory narration, “A Journey of Dmitry Shostakovich” peeks at the politics of this controversial composer.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Journey of Dmitry Shostakovich

results.headline: Stark Images of Privation, and Diary as Confession
results.summary_short: The documentaries “Blockade” and “Amateur Photographer” offer a devastating look at World War II-era atrocities.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blockade

results.headline: It Came From the River, Hungry for Humans (Burp)
results.summary_short: “The Host” is a loopy, feverishly imaginative genre hybrid about the demons that haunt us from without and within.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Host

results.headline: Grandpa’s Legacy, Beyond Cash
results.summary_short: Reeking of self-righteousness and moral reprimand, “The Ultimate Gift” is a hairball of good-for-you filmmaking.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Ultimate Gift

results.headline: Film Review: Modernity and Tradition at a Cultural Crossroads
results.summary_short: Mira Nair’s “The Namesake," based on Jhumpa Lahiri's novel, conveys a palpable sense of people as living, breathing creatures who are far more complex than their words might indicate.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Namesake

results.headline: Big Wishes, Easy Credit, Tough Times
results.summary_short: “Maxed Out” examines why the most vulnerable segment of society is victimized by the lending industry and finds a simple answer: It’s obscenely profitable.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Maxed Out

results.headline: From a Schoolhouse in Rwanda, Wrenching Lessons About Genocide
results.summary_short: “Beyond the Gates,” a harrowing recounting of the 1994 Rwandan genocide, packs a hard punch.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beyond the Gates

results.headline: A Doctor’s Surprise Case: His Lieutenant’s Wife
results.summary_short: “Border Post” is a profane and playful military drama about boredom, duty and the consequences of reckless lust.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Border Post

results.headline: Hunting a Killer as the Age of Aquarius Dies
results.summary_short: David Fincher’s magnificently obsessive new film, “Zodiac,” is part police procedural, part monster movie, a funereal entertainment that is a testament to this cinematic savant’s gifts.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Zodiac

results.headline: Hitting the Road for Some Hot Man-on-Bike Action
results.summary_short: The main thing about the guys in “Wild Hogs” — the main source of the movie’s fumbling attempts at humor — is that they’re not gay. Really. Seriously. No way.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wild Hogs

results.headline: Lessons in Surviving a Mother’s Dying Days
results.summary_short: In the deathbed drama “Two Weeks,” Sally Field creates an agonizing portrait of a middle-aged American everywoman in the final stages of ovarian cancer.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Two Weeks

results.headline: Painting Through the Pain
results.summary_short: The title may suggest a wildlife documentary, but “The Cats of Mirikitani” is entirely, vibrantly human.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Cats of Mirikitani

results.headline: Addiction, Magnified
results.summary_short: A graphic study of sex and drug addiction, “Rock Bottom” goes beyond the pieties of the recovery movements to confront deeper questions about the pursuit of sensation.
results.display_title: Rock Bottom: Gay Men and Meth

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rock Bottom: Gay Men and Meth

results.headline: A Loner Wanders Junior High, as a Lion Strays on Campus
results.summary_short: The moment at the dawn of adolescence when hormones and daydreams swirl into a heady fog of confusion is poetically evoked in “Wild Tigers I Have Known.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wild Tigers I Have Known

results.headline: Haunted by Ghosts of the Past, Beckoned by a Homeland
results.summary_short: Through the murk and gloom of “The Abandoned,” a mystery emerges: Why didn’t this go straight to DVD?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Abandoned

results.headline: A Tale of Love, Drought and Desperation
results.summary_short: “The Wayward Cloud” offers one plausible moral:  If life hands you watermelons, make love to them.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Wayward Cloud

results.headline: Laying Down the Law, Just for Laughs
results.summary_short: “Reno 911!: Miami” is slapdash, on-and-off funny and exceedingly lazy.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Reno 911: Miami
